block.p: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

'Stay the Course' Gone From Bush's Iraq Remarks The White House said President Bush was no longer using the phrase ''stay the course'' when speaking about the Iraq war, in a new effort to emphasize flexibility in the face of some of the bloodiest violence there since the 2003 invasion.
An American soldier apparently working as a translator disappeared in Baghdad, the military said.
Economy Strengthens Sudan Oil has turned Sudan into one of the fastest-growing economies in Africa, giving the nation's government the ability to resist Western demands to end the conflict in Darfur.
A1

Iran Tests Nuclear Equipment The head of the International Atomic Energy Agency said Iran has begun testing new uranium-enrichment equipment that could double the capacity of its small research-and-development facilities.

Israeli Premier Broadens Base Prime Minister Ehud Olmert reached a deal to broaden his shaky coalition by adding a far-right party that seeks to annex parts of the West Bank and to eventually reduce Israel's Arab population.
A8

Italy to Replace Its Top Spy Italy's top spy is expected to be replaced, with prosecutors saying they intend to seek his indictment on charges connected to the abduction of an Egyptian cleric in Milan in 2003 by American intelligence agents.
A3

Hungary Riots Mar Anniversary Violent clashes in Budapest marred the 50th anniversary of Hungary's 1956 uprising against Soviet domination, as the police tried to contain a month-old anti-government protest movement.
NATIONAL A16-26

Power of Independents Rises as Election Nears People in Arizona who reject the old major party labels are by far the fastest-growing category of voter, with the number of independents doubling over the last 10 years. If the trend continues, it could not only lead to more competitive races on the local and statewide level but also in the presidential election.
A1

Coca-Cola Donates to Musuem Coca-Cola said it would donate two and a half acres of land near the downtown tourist district in Atlanta to a proposed civil rights museum that would hold, among other exhibits, the papers of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

Lashing Out at the Iraq War A brother of Pat Tillman, the popular National Football League player who was killed in combat in Afghanistan after giving up his sports career to serve in the Army, has lashed out at the Iraq war in an essay published online.

Sources Sought From Times A federal magistrate judge has ordered The New York Times to disclose the identities of confidential sources used by one of its columnists, Nicholas D. Kristof, for articles he wrote about the investigation of the deadly anthrax mailings of 2001. A21
EDUCATION

Loan Companies Woo Colleges With rising tuition and lagging government aid making private student loans a big, increasingly competitive business, loan companies are offering lavish gifts like trips to the Caribbean, iPods and DVD players to court universities to steer students their way. A1
NEW YORK/REGION B1-8
Experts Clash on Linking Some Deaths to Sept. 11

The New York City medical examiner's office has refused to put the name of a woman, whose death was the first to be formally linked to the toxic air at ground zero, on its official list of 9/11 victims, stating there was insufficient medical evidence to link the woman's death to the dust. A1

Hevesi Accused of Illegality The State Ethics Commission accused Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi of breaking the law by using state employees to chauffeur his wife. The commission's 26-page report dealt a serious blow to Mr. Hevesi, who is running for re-election. B1
3 Dead in Bronx Beating Three people were bludgeoned to death, probably with a dumbbell and a metal pipe, in the basement of a Bronx apartment building. B1
SCIENCE TIMES F1-8
AIDS Drugs Uncover Leprosy With affordable AIDS drugs arriving in many poor countries, the treatment uncovers a hidden leprosy infection in some patients. F1
Peaceful Nuclear Uses The International Atomic Energy Agency is working hard to foster peaceful uses for nuclear science including methods of dating and authenticating art. F1

Tumor Types Between Races African-American women with breast cancer have lower survival rates compared with white women, and a new study suggests that one reason may be a difference in tumor biology between the races. F7
Health & Fitness F5-8
BUSINESS DAY C1-13

Ford Reports Sizable Loss The Ford Motor Company reported a $5.8 billion third-quarter loss, its worst results in more than 14 years, as it and other Detroit auto companies continue to struggle to reinvent themselves. A1
Business Digest C2
EDITORIAL A28-29
Editorial: Trying to contain the Iraq disaster.
Columns: John Tierney, Nicholas D. Kristof.
